summary:
The Security Council,
 
Recalling its resolutions 2042 (2012), 2043 (2012), 2118 (2013), 2139 (2014), 2165 (2014), 2175 (2014), 2191 (2014), 2209 (2015), 2235 (2015), 2254 (2015), 2258 (2015), 2268 (2016), 2286 (2016), 2332 (2016), 2336 (2016), 2393 (2017) and 2401 (2018) and its Presidential Statements, 
 
Reaffirming commitment to Syria's sovereignty, independence, unity and territorial integrity, 
 
Expressing outrage at the level of violence, killing of hundreds of thousands, including tens of thousands of children, 
 
 Reiterating grave distress at the humanitarian situation, 13 million people requiring assistance, 6.2 million internally displaced, 1 million in hard-to-reach areas, 
 
Gravely concerned at insufficient implementation of resolutions, violations of international humanitarian law and human rights law, attacks on civilians, schools, medical facilities, 
 
Noting progress in taking back areas from ISIL and ANF, but expressing concern at their continued presence and negative impact, 
 
Expressing concern at foreign terrorist fighters, calling for prevention and suppression of their flow, 
 
Reaffirming obligations under international law, particularly human rights, refugee and humanitarian law, 
 
Reaffirming Syrian authorities' primary responsibility to protect the population, 
 
 Reiterating condemnation of violence against humanitarian operations, attacks on convoys, destruction and looting, 
 
Noting humanitarian aid delivery to 5.4 million people monthly in 2018, 
 
 Reiterating grave concern at hindrances to humanitarian assistance, particularly by ISIL, ANF and Al-Qaida associated groups.
Here is a summarized version of the Security Council document:

The Security Council expresses grave concern at the humanitarian situation in Syria, citing impediments to delivering sustained, needs-based assistance across the country. It reiterates the need to respect medical neutrality, facilitate free passage for medical personnel and supplies, and enable the immediate and unhindered delivery of humanitarian assistance.

The Council appreciates the work of the UN monitoring mechanism in facilitating cross-border delivery of humanitarian aid and commends efforts to scale up humanitarian deliveries. It emphasizes the importance of upholding humanitarian principles, including humanity, neutrality, impartiality, and independence.

The Council calls upon all parties to respect and uphold international humanitarian law and ceasefire agreements, and to facilitate the safe, voluntary, and dignified return of refugees and internally displaced persons. It urges the international community to increase assistance to Syria, including humanitarian aid, and to support the UN and countries in the region.

The Council strongly condemns arbitrary detention, torture, and kidnappings, and demands the immediate end of these practices. It stresses the need to end impunity for human rights abuses and violations of international humanitarian law, and to bring those responsible to justice.

The Council determines that the humanitarian situation in Syria continues to constitute a threat to peace and security in the region and calls upon all parties to ensure principled, sustained, and improved humanitarian assistance to Syria in 2019. It reiterates its demand that all parties comply with their obligations under international law and demands the full and immediate implementation of all provisions.
The Security Council:

Recalling previous resolutions on Syria (2139 (2014), 2165 (2014), 2191 (2014), 2258 (2015), 2332 (2016), 2393 (2017), and 2401 (2018)), and noting that some violations and abuses may amount to war crimes and crimes against humanity;

3. Renews decisions in paragraphs 2 and 3 of resolution 2165 (2014) for 12 months, until 10 January 2020;

4. Demands safe, unimpeded, and sustained access for UN and partner humanitarian convoys to all requested areas and populations;

5. Reiterates the need for a political solution to the Syrian conflict, recalling resolution 2254 (2015), and stressing that the Syrian people will decide Syria's future;

6. Requests the Secretary-General to brief the Council monthly and provide reports every 60 days on implementation of relevant resolutions;

7. Reaffirms it will take further measures under the Charter in the event of non-compliance with this or previous resolutions;

8. Decides to remain actively seized of the matter.
